member.name: T:Mallenom.ItemCanBeNullAttribute

member.name: T:Mallenom.StringFormatMethodAttribute

member.name: M:Mallenom.StringFormatMethodAttribute.#ctor(System.String)
member.param: Specifies which parameter of an annotated method should be treated as format-string

member.name: T:Mallenom.ValueProviderAttribute
member.summary: For a parameter that is expected to be one of the limited set of values. Specify fields of which type should be used as values for this parameter.

member.name: T:Mallenom.InvokerParameterNameAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the function argument should be string literal and match one of the parameters of the caller function. For example, ReSharper annotates the parameter of

member.name: T:Mallenom.NotifyPropertyChangedInvocatorAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the method is contained in a type that implements System.ComponentModel.INotifyPropertyChanged interface and this method is used to notify that some property value changed
member.remarks:
The method should be non-static and conform to one of the supported signatures:
NotifyChanged(string)
NotifyChanged(params string[])
NotifyChanged{T}(Expression{Func{T}})
NotifyChanged{T,U}(Expression{Func{T,U}})
SetProperty{T}(ref T, T, string)

member.name: T:Mallenom.ContractAnnotationAttribute
member.summary: Describes dependency between method input and output
member.syntax:
Function Definition Table syntax:
FDT ::= FDTRow [;FDTRow]*
FDTRow ::= Input => Output | Output <= Input
Input ::= ParameterName: Value [, Input]*
Output ::= [ParameterName: Value]* {halt|stop|void|nothing|Value}
Value ::= true | false | null | notnull | canbenull
If method has single input parameter, it's name could be omitted.
Using halt (or void/nothing, which is the same) for method output means that the methos doesn't return normally.
canbenull annotation is only applicable for output parameters.
You can use multiple [ContractAnnotation] for each FDT row, or use single attribute with rows separated by semicolon.

item.code: [ContractAnnotation("halt <= condition: false")] public void Assert(bool condition, string text) // regular assertion method
[ContractAnnotation("s:null => true")] public bool IsNullOrEmpty(string s) // string.IsNullOrEmpty()
[ContractAnnotation("s:null=>false; =>true,result:notnull; =>false, result:null")] public bool TryParse(string s, out Person result)

member.name: T:Mallenom.LocalizationRequiredAttribute

member.summary: FOURCC- .
member.remarks: source: http://www.fourcc.org/

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.BI_RGB
member.summary: This is the basic RBG bitmap format which comes in all the common bits per pixel flavours. 1, 4 and 8 bpp versions of the format are palettised and 16, 24 and 32 bpp contain direct colour information. In all cases, the bitmap comprises a rectangular array of packed pixels.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.RGB
member.summary: Alias for .

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.BI_RLE8
member.summary: Run length encoded 8bpp RGB image.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.RLE8
member.summary: Alias for .

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.BI_RLE4
member.summary: Run length encoded 4bpp RGB image.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.RLE
member.summary: Alias for .

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.BI_BITFIELDS
member.summary: Raw RGB with arbitrary sample packing within a pixel. Packing and precision of R, G and B components is determined by bit masks for each.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.raw
member.summary: raw, uncompressed RGB bitmap.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.RGBA
member.summary: Raw RGB with alpha. Sample precision and packing is arbitrary and determined using bit masks for each component, as for .

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.RGBT
member.summary: Raw RGB with a transparency field. Layout is as for at 16 and 32 bits per pixel but the msb in each pixel indicates whether the pixel is transparent or not.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.AYUV
member.summary: This is a 4:4:4 YUV format with 8 bit samples for each component along with an 8 bit alpha blend value per pixel. Component ordering is A Y U V (as the name suggests).

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.CLJR
member.summary: Cirrus Logic's format packs 4 pixel samples into a single u_int32 by sacrificing precision on each sample. Y samples are truncated to 5 bits each, U and V have 6 bits per sample.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.cyuv
member.summary: Essentially a copy of except that the sense of the height is reversed - the image is upside down with respect to the version.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.GREY
member.summary: Apparently a duplicate of (and also, presumably, ).

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.IRAW
member.summary: Intel uncompressed YUV.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.IUYV
member.summary: Interlaced version of (line order 0, 2, 4,....,1, 3, 5....) registered by Silviu Brinzei of LEAD Technologies.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.IY41
member.summary: Interlaced version of (line order 0, 2, 4,....,1, 3, 5....) registered by Silviu Brinzei of LEAD Technologies.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.IYU1
member.summary: The IYU1 format is a 12 bit format used in mode 2 of the IEEE 1394 Digital Camera 1.04 spec ("1394-based Digital Camera Specification, Version 1.04, August 9, 1996", page 14.). The format, a duplicate of , is YUV (4:1:1).

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.IYU2
member.summary: 24 bit format used in mode 0 of the IEEE 1394 Digital Camera 1.04 spec The format is YUV (4:4:4).

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.HDYC
member.summary: YUV 4:2:2 (Y sample at every pixel, U and V sampled at every second pixel horizontally on each line). A macropixel contains 2 pixels in 1 u_int32. This is a suplicate of except that the color components use the BT709 color space (as used in HD video).

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.UYNV
member.summary: A direct copy of registered by NVidia to work around problems in some old codecs which did not like hardware which offered more than 2 UYVY surfaces.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.UYVP
member.summary: YCbCr 4:2:2 extended precision 10-bits per component in U0Y0V0Y1 order. Registered by Rich Ehlers of Evans & Sutherland.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.UYVY
member.summary: YUV 4:2:2 (Y sample at every pixel, U and V sampled at every second pixel horizontally on each line). A macropixel contains 2 pixels in 1 u_int32.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.V210
member.summary: 10-bit 4:2:2 YCrCb equivalent to the Quicktime format of the same name.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.V422
member.summary: Upside-down version of .

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.V655
member.summary: 16 bit YUV 4:2:2 format registered by Vitec Multimedia.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.VYUY
member.summary: ATI Packed YUV Data.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.Y422
member.summary: Direct copy of as used by ADS Technologies Pyro WebCam firewire camera.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.YUY2
member.summary: YUV 4:2:2 as for but with different component ordering within the u_int32 macropixel.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.YUYV
member.summary: Duplicate of .

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.YUNV
member.summary: A direct copy of registered by NVidia to work around problems in some old codecs which did not like hardware which offered more than 2 YUY2 surfaces.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.YVYU
member.summary: YUV 4:2:2 as for but with different component ordering within the u_int32 macropixel.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.Y41P
member.summary: YUV 4:1:1 (Y sample at every pixel, U and V sampled at every fourth pixel horizontally on each line). A macropixel contains 8 pixels in 3 u_int32s.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.Y411
member.summary: YUV 4:1:1 with a packed, 6 byte/4 pixel macroblock structure.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.Y211
member.summary: Packed YUV format with Y sampled at every second pixel across each line and U and V sampled at every fourth pixel.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.Y41T
member.summary: Format as for but the lsb of each Y component is used to signal pixel transparency.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.Y42T
member.summary: Format as for but the lsb of each Y component is used to signal pixel transparency.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.YUVP
member.summary: YCbCr 4:2:2 extended precision 10-bits per component in Y0U0Y1V0 order. Registered by Rich Ehlers of Evans & Sutherland.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.YVU9
member.summary: 8 bit Y plane followed by 8 bit 4x4 subsampled V and U planes. Registered by Intel.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.YUV9
member.summary: Registered by Intel, this is the format used internally by Indeo video codec.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.IF09
member.summary: As but an additional 4x4 subsampled plane is appended containing delta information relative to the last frame. (Bpp is reported as 9).

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.YV16
member.summary: 8 bit Y plane followed by 8 bit 2x1 subsampled V and U planes.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.YV12
member.summary: 8 bit Y plane followed by 8 bit 2x2 subsampled V and U planes.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.I420
member.summary: 8 bit Y plane followed by 8 bit 2x2 subsampled U and V planes.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.IYUV
member.summary: Duplicate FOURCC, identical to .

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.NV12
member.summary: 8-bit Y plane followed by an interleaved U/V plane with 2x2 subsampling.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.NV21
member.summary: As . with U and V reversed in the interleaved plane.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.IMC1
member.summary: As except the U and V planes each have the same stride as the Y plane.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.IMC2
member.summary: Similar to except that the U and V lines are interleaved at half stride boundaries.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.IMC3
member.summary: As except that U and V are swapped.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.IMC4
member.summary: As except that U and V are swapped.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.CLPL
member.summary: Format similar to YV12 but including a level of indirection.

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.Y41B
member.summary: Weitek format listed as "YUV 4:1:1 planar".

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.Y42B
member.summary: Weitek format listed as "YUV 4:2:2 planar".

member.name: F:Mallenom.Imaging.ColorSpaceFOURCC.Y800
member.summary: Simple, single Y plane for monochrome images.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.INVALID_HANDLE_VALUE
member.summary: Invalid handle value.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.HWND_BOTTOM
member.summary: Places the window at the bottom of the Z order. If the hWnd parameter identifies a topmost window, the window loses its topmost status and is placed at the bottom of all other windows.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.HWND_NOTOPMOST
member.summary: Places the window above all non-topmost windows (that is, behind all topmost windows). This flag has no effect if the window is already a non-topmost window.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.HWND_TOP
member.summary: Places the window at the top of the Z order.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.HWND_TOPMOST
member.summary: Places the window above all non-topmost windows. The window maintains its topmost position even when it is deactivated.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.FILE_SHARE_NONE
member.summary: Prevents other processes from opening a file or device if they request delete, read, or write access.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.FILE_SHARE_READ
member.summary: Enables subsequent open operations on a file or device to request read access. Otherwise, other processes cannot open the file or device if they request read access. If this flag is not specified, but the file or device has been opened for read access, the function fails.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.FILE_SHARE_WRITE
member.summary: Enables subsequent open operations on a file or device to request write access. Otherwise, other processes cannot open the file or device if they request write access. If this flag is not specified, but the file or device has been opened for write access or has a file mapping with write access, the function fails.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.FILE_SHARE_DELETE
member.summary: Enables subsequent open operations on a file or device to request delete access. Otherwise, other processes cannot open the file or device if they request delete access. If this flag is not specified, but the file or device has been opened for delete access, the function fails.
member.remarks: Delete access allows both delete and rename operations.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.CREATE_ALWAYS
member.summary: Creates a new file, always. If the specified file exists and is writable, the function overwrites the file, the function succeeds, and last-error code is set to ERROR_ALREADY_EXISTS (183). If the specified file does not exist and is a valid path, a new file is created, the function succeeds, and the last-error code is set to zero.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.CREATE_NEW
member.summary: Creates a new file, only if it does not already exist. If the specified file exists, the function fails and the last-error code is set to ERROR_FILE_EXISTS (80). If the specified file does not exist and is a valid path to a writable location, a new file is created.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.OPEN_ALWAYS
member.summary: Opens a file, always. If the specified file exists, the function succeeds and the last-error code is set to ERROR_ALREADY_EXISTS (183). If the specified file does not exist and is a valid path to a writable location, the function creates a file and the last-error code is set to zero.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.OPEN_EXISTING
member.summary: Opens a file or device, only if it exists. If the specified file or device does not exist, the function fails and the last-error code is set to ERROR_FILE_NOT_FOUND (2).

member.name: F:Native.Constants.TRUNCATE_EXISTING
member.summary: Opens a file and truncates it so that its size is zero bytes, only if it exists. If the specified file does not exist, the function fails and the last-error code is set to ERROR_FILE_NOT_FOUND (2). The calling process must open the file with the GENERIC_WRITE bit set as part of the dwDesiredAccess parameter.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_ARCHIVE
member.summary: The file should be archived. Applications use this attribute to mark files for backup or removal.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_ENCRYPTED
member.summary: The file or directory is encrypted. For a file, this means that all data in the file is encrypted. For a directory, this means that encryption is the default for newly created files and subdirectories. This flag has no effect if is also specified. This flag is not supported on Home, Home Premium, Starter, or ARM editions of Windows.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_HIDDEN
member.summary: The file is hidden. Do not include it in an ordinary directory listing.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_NORMAL
member.summary: The file does not have other attributes set. This attribute is valid only if used alone.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_OFFLINE
member.summary: The data of a file is not immediately available. This attribute indicates that file data is physically moved to offline storage. This attribute is used by Remote Storage, the hierarchical storage management software. Applications should not arbitrarily change this attribute.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_READONLY
member.summary: The file is read only. Applications can read the file, but cannot write to or delete it.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_SYSTEM
member.summary: The file is part of or used exclusively by an operating system.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_TEMPORARY
member.summary: The file is being used for temporary storage.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.FILE_FLAG_BACKUP_SEMANTICS
member.summary: The file is being opened or created for a backup or restore operation. The system ensures that the calling process overrides file security checks when the process has SE_BACKUP_NAME and SE_RESTORE_NAME privileges. You must set this flag to obtain a handle to a directory. A directory handle can be passed to some functions instead of a file handle.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.FILE_FLAG_DELETE_ON_CLOSE
member.summary: The file is to be deleted immediately after all of its handles are closed, which includes the specified handle and any other open or duplicated handles. If there are existing open handles to a file, the call fails unless they were all opened with the share mode. Subsequent open requests for the file fail, unless the FILE_SHARE_DELETE share mode is specified.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.FILE_FLAG_NO_BUFFERING
member.summary: The file or device is being opened with no system caching for data reads and writes. This flag does not affect hard disk caching or memory mapped files.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.FILE_FLAG_OPEN_NO_RECALL
member.summary: The file data is requested, but it should continue to be located in remote storage. It should not be transported back to local storage. This flag is for use by remote storage systems.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.FILE_FLAG_OPEN_REPARSE_POINT
member.summary: Normal reparse point processing will not occur; CreateFile will attempt to open the reparse point. When a file is opened, a file handle is returned, whether or not the filter that controls the reparse point is operational. This flag cannot be used with the flag. If the file is not a reparse point, then this flag is ignored.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.FILE_FLAG_OVERLAPPED
member.summary: The file or device is being opened or created for asynchronous I/O. When subsequent I/O operations are completed on this handle, the event specified in the OVERLAPPED structure will be set to the signaled state. If this flag is specified, the file can be used for simultaneous read and write operations. If this flag is not specified, then I/O operations are serialized, even if the calls to the read and write functions specify an OVERLAPPED structure.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.FILE_FLAG_POSIX_SEMANTICS
member.summary: Access will occur according to POSIX rules. This includes allowing multiple files with names, differing only in case, for file systems that support that naming. Use care when using this option, because files created with this flag may not be accessible by applications that are written for MS-DOS or 16-bit Windows.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.FILE_FLAG_RANDOM_ACCESS
member.summary: Access is intended to be random. The system can use this as a hint to optimize file caching. This flag has no effect if the file system does not support cached I/O and .

member.name: F:Native.Constants.FILE_FLAG_SESSION_AWARE
member.summary: The file or device is being opened with session awareness. If this flag is not specified, then per-session devices (such as a redirected USB device) cannot be opened by processes running in session 0. This flag has no effect for callers not in session 0. This flag is supported only on server editions of Windows.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.FILE_FLAG_SEQUENTIAL_SCAN
member.summary: Access is intended to be sequential from beginning to end. The system can use this as a hint to optimize file caching. This flag should not be used if read-behind (that is, reverse scans) will be used. This flag has no effect if the file system does not support cached I/O and .

member.name: F:Native.Constants.FILE_FLAG_WRITE_THROUGH
member.summary: Write operations will not go through any intermediate cache, they will go directly to disk.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.GENERIC_READ
member.summary: Read access.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.GENERIC_WRITE
member.summary: Write access.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.GENERIC_EXECUTE
member.summary: Execute access.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.GENERIC_ALL
member.summary: All possible access rights.

member.summary: Application instance handle.

member.name: F:Native.Constants.GWL_STYLE

member.name: F:Native.Constants.GWLP_USERDATA

member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is the result of the multiplication and division, rounded to the nearest integer. If the result is a positive half integer (ends in .5), it is rounded up. If the result is a negative half integer, it is rounded down. member.name: M:Native.Kernel32.CreateFile(System.String,System.UInt32,System.UInt32,System.IntPtr,System.UInt32,System.UInt32,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Creates or opens a file or I/O device. The most commonly used I/O devices are as follows: file, file stream, directory, physical disk, volume, console buffer, tape drive, communications resource, mailslot, and pipe. The function returns a handle that can be used to access the file or device for various types of I/O depending on the file or device and the flags and attributes specified.
member.param: The name of the file or device to be created or opened. You may use either forward slashes (/) or backslashes (\) in this name.
The requested access to the file or device, which can be summarized as read, write, both or neither zero).

The requested sharing mode of the file or device, which can be read, write, both, delete, all of these, or none (refer to the following table). Access requests to attributes or extended attributes are not affected by this flag.

A pointer to a SECURITY_ATTRIBUTES structure that contains two separate but related data members: an optional security descriptor, and a Boolean value that determines whether the returned handle can be inherited by child processes.
An action to take on a file or device that exists or does not exist.
The file or device attributes and flags, being the most common default value for files.
A valid handle to a template file with the GENERIC_READ access right. The template file supplies file attributes and extended attributes for the file that is being created.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is an open handle to the specified file, device, named pipe, or mail slot. If the function fails, the return value is .

member.summary: Sends a control code directly to a specified device driver, causing the corresponding device to perform the corresponding operation.
member.param: A handle to the device on which the operation is to be performed. The device is typically a volume, directory, file, or stream. To retrieve a device handle, use the function.
The control code for the operation. This value identifies the specific operation to be performed and the type of device on which to perform it.

A pointer to the input buffer that contains the data required to perform the operation. The format of this data depends on the value of the parameter. This parameter can be NULL if specifies an operation that does not require input data.
The size of the input buffer, in bytes.

A pointer to the output buffer that is to receive the data returned by the operation. The format of this data depends on the value of the parameter. This parameter can be NULL if specifies an operation that does not return data.
The size of the output buffer, in bytes.
A pointer to a variable that receives the size of the data stored in the output buffer, in bytes.
A pointer to an OVERLAPPED structure. If hDevice was opened without specifying , is ignored.
member.returns: If the operation completes successfully, the return value is nonzero. If the operation fails or is pending, the return value is zero.

member.name: F:Native.Kernel32.WaitForMultipleObjectsEntryPoint
member.summary: WaitForMultipleObjects.

member.name: M:Native.Kernel32.WaitForMultipleObjects(System.Int32,System.IntPtr[],System.Boolean,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Waits until one or all of the specified objects are in the signaled state or the time-out interval elapses. To enter an alertable wait state, use the function.
member.param: The number of object handles in the array pointed to by lpHandles. The maximum number of object handles is . This parameter cannot be zero.
An array of object handles. The array can contain handles to objects of different types. It may not contain multiple copies of the same handle.

If this parameter is true, the function returns when the state of all objects in the lpHandles array is signaled. If false, the function returns when the state of any one of the objects is set to signaled. In the latter case, the return value indicates the object whose state caused the function to return.

The time-out interval, in milliseconds. If a nonzero value is specified, the function waits until the specified objects are signaled or the interval elapses. If dwMilliseconds is zero, the function does not enter a wait state if the specified objects are not signaled; it always returns immediately. If dwMilliseconds is , the function will return only when the specified objects are signaled.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value indicates the event that caused the function to return.

member.name: F:Native.Kernel32.WaitForMultipleObjectsExEntryPoint
member.summary: WaitForMultipleObjectsEx.

member.name: M:Native.Kernel32.WaitForMultipleObjectsEx(System.Int32,System.IntPtr[],System.Boolean,System.UInt32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Waits until one or all of the specified objects are in the signaled state, an I/O completion routine or asynchronous procedure call (APC) is queued to the thread, or the time-out interval elapses.
member.param: The number of object handles in the array pointed to by lpHandles. The maximum number of object handles is . This parameter cannot be zero.
An array of object handles. The array can contain handles to objects of different types. It may not contain multiple copies of the same handle.

If this parameter is true, the function returns when the state of all objects in the lpHandles array is signaled. If false, the function returns when the state of any one of the objects is set to signaled. In the latter case, the return value indicates the object whose state caused the function to return.

The time-out interval, in milliseconds. If a nonzero value is specified, the function waits until the specified objects are signaled or the interval elapses. If dwMilliseconds is zero, the function does not enter a wait state if the specified objects are not signaled; it always returns immediately. If dwMilliseconds is , the function will return only when the specified objects are signaled.

If this parameter is TRUE and the thread is in the waiting state, the function returns when the system queues an I/O completion routine or APC, and the thread runs the routine or function. Otherwise, the function does not return and the completion routine or APC function is not executed.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value indicates the event that caused the function to return.

member.name: M:Native.Kernel32.GetShortPathName(System.String,System.Char[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves the short path form of the specified path.
member.param: The path string. In the ANSI version of this function, the name is limited to MAX_PATH characters. To extend this limit to 32,767 wide characters, call the Unicode version of the function and prepend "\\?\" to the path.

A pointer to a buffer to receive the null-terminated short form of the path that specifies. Passing NULL for this parameter and zero for cchBuffer will always return the required buffer size for a specified .
The size of the buffer that points to, in chars. Set this parameter to zero if is set to null.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is the length, in TCHARs, of the string that is copied to , not including the terminating null character. If the lpszShortPath buffer is too small to contain the path, the return value is the size of the buffer, in TCHARs, that is required to hold the path and the terminating null character. If the function fails for any other reason, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError().

member.name: M:Native.Kernel32.LoadLibrary(System.String)
member.summary: Loads the specified module into the address space of the calling process. The specified module may cause other modules to be loaded. For additional load options, use the function.
member.param: The name of the module. This can be either a library module (a .dll file) or an executable module (an .exe file). The name specified is the file name of the module and is not related to the name stored in the library module itself, as specified by the LIBRARY keyword in the module-definition (.def) file. If the string specifies a full path, the function searches only that path for the module. If the string specifies a relative path or a module name without a path, the function uses a standard search strategy to find the module. If the function cannot find the module, the function fails.When specifying a path, be sure to use backslashes (\), not forward slashes(/). For more information about paths, see Naming a File or Directory. If the string specifies a module name without a path and the file name extension is omitted, the function appends the default library extension .dll to the module name.To prevent the function from appending .dll to the module name, include a trailing point character (.) in the module name string.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is a handle to the module. If the function fails, the return value is invalid handle. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

member.name: M:Native.Kernel32.LoadLibraryEx(System.String,System.IntPtr,Native.LoadLibraryFlags)
member.summary: Loads the specified module into the address space of the calling process. The specified module may cause other modules to be loaded.
member.param: The name of the module. This can be either a library module (a .dll file) or an executable module (an .exe file). The name specified is the file name of the module and is not related to the name stored in the library module itself, as specified by the LIBRARY keyword in the module-definition (.def) file. If the string specifies a full path, the function searches only that path for the module. If the string specifies a relative path or a module name without a path, the function uses a standard search strategy to find the module. If the function cannot find the module, the function fails.When specifying a path, be sure to use backslashes (\), not forward slashes(/). For more information about paths, see Naming a File or Directory. If the string specifies a module name without a path and the file name extension is omitted, the function appends the default library extension .dll to the module name.To prevent the function from appending .dll to the module name, include a trailing point character (.) in the module name string.
This parameter is reserved for future use. It must be .
The action to be taken when loading the module. If no flags are specified, the behavior of this function is identical to that of the function.

member.name: M:Native.Gdi32.StretchBlt(System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Native.RasterOperation)
member.summary: The StretchBlt function copies a bitmap from a source rectangle into a destination rectangle, stretching or compressing the bitmap to fit the dimensions of the destination rectangle, if necessary. The system stretches or compresses the bitmap according to the stretching mode currently set in the destination device context.
member.param: A handle to the destination device context.
The x-coordinate, in logical units, of the upper-left corner of the destination rectangle.
The y-coordinate, in logical units, of the upper-left corner of the destination rectangle.
The width, in logical units, of the destination rectangle.
The height, in logical units, of the destination rectangle.
A handle to the source device context.
The x-coordinate, in logical units, of the upper-left corner of the source rectangle.
The y-coordinate, in logical units, of the upper-left corner of the source rectangle.
The width, in logical units, of the source rectangle.
The height, in logical units, of the source rectangle.
The raster operation to be performed. Raster operation codes define how the system combines colors in output operations that involve a brush, a source bitmap, and a destination bitmap.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is true. If the function fails, the return value is false.

member.name: F:Native.Gdi32.BitBltEntryPoint
member.summary: StretchBlt.

member.name: M:Native.Gdi32.BitBlt(System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32,Native.RasterOperation)
member.summary: The BitBlt function performs a bit-block transfer of the color data corresponding to a rectangle of pixels from the specified source device context into a destination device context.
member.param: A handle to the destination device context.
The x-coordinate, in logical units, of the upper-left corner of the destination rectangle.
The y-coordinate, in logical units, of the upper-left corner of the destination rectangle.
The width, in logical units, of the source and destination rectangles.
The height, in logical units, of the source and the destination rectangles.
A handle to the source device context.
The x-coordinate, in logical units, of the upper-left corner of the source rectangle.
The y-coordinate, in logical units, of the upper-left corner of the source rectangle.
A raster-operation code. These codes define how the color data for the source rectangle is to be combined with the color data for the destination rectangle to achieve the final color.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is true. If the function fails, the return value is false.

member.name: F:Native.Gdi32.StretchDIBitsEntryPoint
member.summary: StretchDIBits.

member.name: M:Native.Gdi32.StretchDIBits(System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,Native.DibUsage,Native.RasterOperation)
member.summary: The StretchDIBits function copies the color data for a rectangle of pixels in a DIB, JPEG, or PNG image to the specified destination rectangle. If the destination rectangle is larger than the source rectangle, this function stretches the rows and columns of color data to fit the destination rectangle. If the destination rectangle is smaller than the source rectangle, this function compresses the rows and columns by using the specified raster operation.
member.param: A handle to the destination device context.
The x-coordinate, in logical units, of the upper-left corner of the destination rectangle.
The y-coordinate, in logical units, of the upper-left corner of the destination rectangle.
The width, in logical units, of the destination rectangle.
The height, in logical units, of the destination rectangle.
The x-coordinate, in pixels, of the source rectangle in the image.
The y-coordinate, in pixels, of the source rectangle in the image.
The width, in pixels, of the source rectangle in the image.
The height, in pixels, of the source rectangle in the image.
A pointer to the image bits, which are stored as an array of bytes.
A pointer to a BITMAPINFO structure that contains information about the DIB.
A raster-operation code that specifies how the source pixels, the destination device context's current brush, and the destination pixels are to be combined to form the new image.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is the number of scan lines copied. Note that this value can be negative for mirrored content. If the function fails, or no scan lines are copied, the return value is 0.

member.name: F:Native.Gdi32.SelectObjectEntryPoint
member.summary: SelectObject.

member.name: M:Native.Gdi32.SelectObject(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: The SelectObject function selects an object into the specified device context (DC). The new object replaces the previous object of the same type.
member.param: A handle to the DC.
A handle to the object to be selected.
member.returns: If the selected object is not a region and the function succeeds, the return value is a handle to the object being replaced. If the selected object is a region and the function succeeds, the return value is one of the following values: SIMPLEREGION, COMPLEXREGION, NULLREGION. If an error occurs and the selected object is not a region, the return value is NULL. Otherwise, it is HGDI_ERROR.
member.remarks: This function returns the previously selected object of the specified type. An application should always replace a new object with the original, default object after it has finished drawing with the new object. An application cannot select a single bitmap into more than one DC at a time.

member.name: F:Native.Gdi32.DeleteObjectEntryPoint
member.summary: DeleteObject.

member.name: M:Native.Gdi32.DeleteObject(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: The DeleteObject function deletes a logical pen, brush, font, bitmap, region, or palette, freeing all system resources associated with the object. After the object is deleted, the specified handle is no longer valid.
member.param: A handle to a logical pen, brush, font, bitmap, region, or palette.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is true. If the specified handle is not valid or is currently selected into a DC, the return value is false.
member.remarks: Do not delete a drawing object (pen or brush) while it is still selected into a DC. When a pattern brush is deleted, the bitmap associated with the brush is not deleted. The bitmap must be deleted independently.

member.name: F:Native.Gdi32.CreateCompatibleDCEntryPoint
member.summary: CreateCompatibleDC.

member.name: M:Native.Gdi32.CreateCompatibleDC(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: The CreateCompatibleDC function creates a memory device context (DC) compatible with the specified device.
member.param: A handle to an existing DC. If this handle is NULL, the function creates a memory DC compatible with the application's current screen.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is the handle to a memory DC. If the function fails, the return value is NULL.

member.name: F:Native.Gdi32.DeleteDCEntryPoint
member.summary: DeleteDC.

member.name: M:Native.Gdi32.DeleteDC(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: The DeleteDC function deletes the specified device context (DC).
member.param: A handle to the device context.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is true. If the function fails, the return value is false.
member.remarks: An application must not delete a DC whose handle was obtained by calling the GetDC function. Instead, it must call the ReleaseDC function to free the DC.

member.param: A handle to the DC.
The item to be returned.
member.returns: The return value specifies the value of the desired item. When nIndex is and the device has 15bpp or 16bpp, the return value is 16.

The bitmap width, in pixels.
The bitmap height, in pixels.

member.param: The type of stock object.

member.name: F:Native.User32.AttachThreadInputEntryPoint
member.summary: AttachThreadInput.

member.name: M:Native.User32.AttachThreadInput(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Attaches or detaches the input processing mechanism of one thread to that of another thread.
member.param: The identifier of the thread to be attached to another thread. The thread to be attached cannot be a system thread.
The identifier of the thread to which idAttach will be attached. This thread cannot be a system thread. A thread cannot attach to itself. Therefore, idAttachTo cannot equal idAttach.
If this parameter is true, the two threads are attached. If the parameter is false, the threads are detached.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is true. If the function fails, the return value is false. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

member.name: F:Native.User32.AllowSetForegroundWindowEntryPoint
member.summary: AllowSetForegroundWindow.

member.name: M:Native.User32.AllowSetForegroundWindow(System.Int32)
member.summary: Enables the specified process to set the foreground window using the SetForegroundWindow function. The calling process must already be able to set the foreground window. For more information, see Remarks later in this topic.
member.param: The identifier of the process that will be enabled to set the foreground window. If this parameter is ASFW_ANY, all processes will be enabled to set the foreground window.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is true. If the function fails, the return value is false. The function will fail if the calling process cannot set the foreground window. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

member.name: F:Native.User32.LockSetForegroundWindowEntryPoint
member.summary: LockSetForegroundWindow.

member.name: M:Native.User32.LockSetForegroundWindow(Native.LSFW)
member.summary: The foreground process can call the LockSetForegroundWindow function to disable calls to the function.
member.param: Specifies whether to enable or disable calls to .
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is true. If the function fails, the return value is false. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

member.name: F:Native.User32.GetDCEntryPoint
member.summary: GetDC.

member.name: M:Native.User32.GetDC(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: The GetDC function retrieves a handle to a device context (DC) for the client area of a specified window or for the entire screen. You can use the returned handle in subsequent GDI functions to draw in the DC. The device context is an opaque data structure, whose values are used internally by GDI.
member.param: A handle to the window whose DC is to be retrieved. If this value is NULL, GetDC retrieves the DC for the entire screen.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is a handle to the DC for the specified window's client area. If the function fails, the return value is NULL.

member.name: F:Native.User32.ReleaseDCEntryPoint
member.summary: ReleaseDC.

member.name: M:Native.User32.ReleaseDC(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.param: A handle to the window whose DC is to be released.
A handle to the DC to be released.
member.returns: The return value indicates whether the DC was released. If the DC was released, the return value is 1. If the DC was not released, the return value is zero.

member.name: F:Native.User32.ShowWindowEntryPoint
member.summary: ShowWindow.

member.name: M:Native.User32.ShowWindow(System.IntPtr,Native.SW)
member.summary: Sets the specified window's show state.
member.param: A handle to the window.

Controls how the window is to be shown. This parameter is ignored the first time an application calls , if the program that launched the application provides a STARTUPINFO structure. Otherwise, the first time is called, the value should be the value obtained by the WinMain function in its nCmdShow parameter.

member.name: F:Native.User32.GetSystemMetricsEntryPoint
member.summary: GetSystemMetrics.

member.name: M:Native.User32.GetSystemMetrics(Native.SM)
member.summary: Retrieves the specified system metric or system configuration setting.
member.param: The system metric or configuration setting to be retrieved.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is the requested system metric or configuration setting. If the function fails, the return value is 0. GetLastError does not provide extended error information.
member.remarks: Note that all dimensions retrieved by are in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.User32.ScrollDCEntryPoint
member.summary: ScrollDC.

member.name: M:Native.User32.ScrollDC(System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32,Native.RECT@,Native.RECT@,System.IntPtr,Native.RECT@)
member.summary: The ScrollDC function scrolls a rectangle of bits horizontally and vertically.
member.param: Handle to the device context that contains the bits to be scrolled.
Specifies the amount, in device units, of horizontal scrolling. This parameter must be a negative value to scroll to the left.
Specifies the amount, in device units, of vertical scrolling. This parameter must be a negative value to scroll up.

Pointer to a RECT structure containing the coordinates of the bits to be scrolled. The only bits affected by the scroll operation are bits in the intersection of this rectangle and the rectangle specified by lprcClip. If lprcScroll is NULL, the entire client area is used.

Pointer to a RECT structure containing the coordinates of the clipping rectangle. The only bits that will be painted are the bits that remain inside this rectangle after the scroll operation has been completed. If lprcClip is NULL, the entire client area is used.
Handle to the region uncovered by the scrolling process. ScrollDC defines this region; it is not necessarily a rectangle.

Pointer to a RECT structure that receives the coordinates of the rectangle bounding the scrolling update region. This is the largest rectangular area that requires repainting. When the function returns, the values in the structure are in client coordinates, regardless of the mapping mode for the specified device context. This allows applications to use the update region in a call to the InvalidateRgn function, if required.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is false.

member.name: F:Native.User32.ScrollWindowExEntryPoint
member.summary: ScrollWindowEx.

member.name: M:Native.User32.ScrollWindowEx(System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32,Native.RECT@,Native.RECT@,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,Native.ScrollWindowFlags)
member.summary: The ScrollWindowEx function scrolls the contents of the specified window's client area.
member.param: Handle to the window where the client area is to be scrolled.
Specifies the amount, in device units, of horizontal scrolling. This parameter must be a negative value to scroll to the left.
Specifies the amount, in device units, of vertical scrolling. This parameter must be a negative value to scroll up.
Pointer to a structure that specifies the portion of the client area to be scrolled. If this parameter is NULL, the entire client area is scrolled.

Pointer to a RECT structure that contains the coordinates of the clipping rectangle. Only device bits within the clipping rectangle are affected. Bits scrolled from the outside of the rectangle to the inside are painted; bits scrolled from the inside of the rectangle to the outside are not painted. This parameter may be NULL.
Handle to the region that is modified to hold the region invalidated by scrolling. This parameter may be NULL.
Pointer to a RECT structure that receives the boundaries of the rectangle invalidated by scrolling. This parameter may be NULL.
Specifies flags that control scrolling.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is SIMPLEREGION (rectangular invalidated region), COMPLEXREGION (nonrectangular invalidated region; overlapping rectangles), or NULLREGION (no invalidated region). If the function fails, the return value is ERROR.

member.name: M:Native.User32.ScrollWindowEx(System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32,Native.RECT@,Native.RECT@,System.IntPtr,Native.RECT@,Native.ScrollWindowFlags)
member.summary: The ScrollWindowEx function scrolls the contents of the specified window's client area.
member.param: Handle to the window where the client area is to be scrolled.
Specifies the amount, in device units, of horizontal scrolling. This parameter must be a negative value to scroll to the left.
Specifies the amount, in device units, of vertical scrolling. This parameter must be a negative value to scroll up.
Pointer to a structure that specifies the portion of the client area to be scrolled. If this parameter is NULL, the entire client area is scrolled.

Pointer to a RECT structure that contains the coordinates of the clipping rectangle. Only device bits within the clipping rectangle are affected. Bits scrolled from the outside of the rectangle to the inside are painted; bits scrolled from the inside of the rectangle to the outside are not painted. This parameter may be NULL.
Handle to the region that is modified to hold the region invalidated by scrolling. This parameter may be NULL.
Pointer to a RECT structure that receives the boundaries of the rectangle invalidated by scrolling.
Specifies flags that control scrolling.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is SIMPLEREGION (rectangular invalidated region), COMPLEXREGION (nonrectangular invalidated region; overlapping rectangles), or NULLREGION (no invalidated region). If the function fails, the return value is ERROR. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

member.name: F:Native.User32.WindowFromPointEntryPoint
member.summary: WindowFromPoint.

member.name: M:Native.User32.WindowFromPoint(Native.POINT)
member.summary: Retrieves a handle to the window that contains the specified point.
member.param: The point to be checked.
member.returns: The return value is a handle to the window that contains the point. If no window exists at the given point, the return value is NULL. If the point is over a static text control, the return value is a handle to the window under the static text control.

member.name: F:Native.User32.ChildWindowFromPointEntryPoint
member.summary: ChildWindowFromPoint.

member.name: M:Native.User32.ChildWindowFromPoint(System.IntPtr,Native.POINT)
member.summary: Determines which, if any, of the child windows belonging to a parent window contains the specified point. The search is restricted to immediate child windows. Grandchildren, and deeper descendant windows are not searched. To skip certain child windows, use the function.
member.param: A handle to the parent window.
A structure that defines the client coordinates, relative to , of the point to be checked.
member.returns: The return value is a handle to the child window that contains the point, even if the child window is hidden or disabled. If the point lies outside the parent window, the return value is NULL. If the point is within the parent window but not within any child window, the return value is a handle to the parent window.

member.name: F:Native.User32.ChildWindowFromPointExEntryPoint
member.summary: ChildWindowFromPointEx.

member.name: M:Native.User32.ChildWindowFromPointEx(System.IntPtr,Native.POINT,Native.CWP)
member.summary: Determines which, if any, of the child windows belonging to the specified parent window contains the specified point. The function can ignore invisible, disabled, and transparent child windows. The search is restricted to immediate child windows. Grandchildren and deeper descendants are not searched.
member.param: A handle to the parent window.
A structure that defines the client coordinates (relative to ) of the point to be checked.
The child windows to be skipped ().
member.returns: The return value is a handle to the first child window that contains the point and meets the criteria specified by . If the point is within the parent window but not within any child window that meets the criteria, the return value is a handle to the parent window. If the point lies outside the parent window or if the function fails, the return value is NULL.

member.name: F:Native.User32.SendMessageEntryPoint
member.summary: SendMessage.

member.name: M:Native.User32.SendMessage(System.IntPtr,Native.WM,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Sends the specified message to a window or windows. The SendMessage function calls the window procedure for the specified window and does not return until the window procedure has processed the message.
member.param: A handle to the window whose window procedure will receive the message. If this parameter is HWND_BROADCAST ((IntPtr)0xffff), the message is sent to all top-level windows in the system, including disabled or invisible unowned windows, overlapped windows, and pop-up windows; but the message is not sent to child windows.
The message to be sent.
Additional message-specific information.
Additional message-specific information.
member.returns: The return value specifies the result of the message processing; it depends on the message sent.

member.name: F:Native.User32.PostMessageEntryPoint
member.summary: PostMessage.

member.name: M:Native.User32.PostMessage(System.IntPtr,Native.WM,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Places (posts) a message in the message queue associated with the thread that created the specified window and returns without waiting for the thread to process the message.
member.param: A handle to the window whose window procedure is to receive the message. The following values have special meanings. ((IntPtr)0xffff): The message is posted to all top-level windows in the system, including disabled or invisible unowned windows, overlapped windows, and pop-up windows. The message is not posted to child windows. IntPtr.Zero: The function behaves like a call to PostThreadMessage with the dwThreadId parameter set to the identifier of the current thread.
The message to be sent.
Additional message-specific information.
Additional message-specific information.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is true. If the function fails, the return value is false. To get extended error information, call GetLastError. GetLastError returns ERROR_NOT_ENOUGH_QUOTA when the limit is hit.

member.name: M:Native.User32.SetWindowLongPtr(System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Changes an attribute of the specified window. The function also sets a value at the specified offset in the extra window memory.
member.param: A handle to the window and, indirectly, the class to which the window belongs. The function fails if the process that owns the window specified by the hWnd parameter is at a higher process privilege in the UIPI hierarchy than the process the calling thread resides in.

The zero-based offset to the value to be set. Valid values are in the range zero through the number of bytes of extra window memory, minus the size of an integer. To set any other value, specify one of the following values:
The replacement value.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is the previous value of the specified offset. If the function fails, the return value is zero.
member.remarks: Certain window data is cached, so changes you make using will not take effect until you call the function.

member.name: M:Native.User32.GetWindowLongPtr(System.IntPtr,System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves information about the specified window. The function also retrieves the value at a specified offset into the extra window memory.
member.param: A handle to the window and, indirectly, the class to which the window belongs.

The zero-based offset to the value to be retrieved. Valid values are in the range zero through the number of bytes of extra window memory, minus the size of an integer. To retrieve any other value, specify one of the following values:
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is the requested value. If the function fails, the return value is zero.

member.name: M:Native.User32.GetWindowRect(System.IntPtr,Native.RECT@)
member.summary: Retrieves the dimensions of the bounding rectangle of the specified window. The dimensions are given in screen coordinates that are relative to the upper-left corner of the screen.
member.param: A handle to the window.
A pointer to a RECT structure that receives the screen coordinates of the upper-left and lower-right corners of the window.

member.name: M:Native.User32.GetClientRect(System.IntPtr,Native.RECT@)
member.summary: Retrieves the coordinates of a window's client area. The client coordinates specify the upper-left and lower-right corners of the client area. Because client coordinates are relative to the upper-left corner of a window's client area, the coordinates of the upper-left corner are (0,0).
member.param: A handle to the window.
A pointer to a structure that receives the client coordinates. The left and top members are zero. The right and bottom members contain the width and height of the window.

member.name: M:Native.User32.SetWindowPos(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Native.SWP)
member.summary: Changes the size, position, and Z order of a child, pop-up, or top-level window. These windows are ordered according to their appearance on the screen. The topmost window receives the highest rank and is the first window in the Z order.
member.param: A handle to the window.
A handle to the window to precede the positioned window in the Z order. This parameter must be a window handle or one of the following values:
The new position of the left side of the window, in client coordinates.
The new position of the top of the window, in client coordinates.
The new width of the window, in pixels.
The new height of the window, in pixels.
The window sizing and positioning flags.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is true. If the function fails, the return value is false.

member.name: F:Native.User32.SetForegroundWindowEntryPoint
member.summary: SetForegroundWindow.

member.name: M:Native.User32.SetForegroundWindow(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Brings the thread that created the specified window into the foreground and activates the window. Keyboard input is directed to the window, and various visual cues are changed for the user. The system assigns a slightly higher priority to the thread that created the foreground window than it does to other threads.
member.param: A handle to the window that should be activated and brought to the foreground.
member.returns: If the window was brought to the foreground, the return value is nonzero. If the window was not brought to the foreground, the return value is zero.

member.name: F:Native.User32.BringWindowToTopEntryPoint
member.summary: BringWindowToTop.

member.name: M:Native.User32.BringWindowToTop(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Brings the specified window to the top of the Z order. If the window is a top-level window, it is activated. If the window is a child window, the top-level parent window associated with the child window is activated.
member.param: A handle to the window to bring to the top of the Z order.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

member.name: M:Native.User32.RegisterWindowMessage(System.String)
member.summary: Defines a new window message that is guaranteed to be unique throughout the system. The message value can be used when sending or posting messages.
member.param: The message to be registered.
member.returns: If the message is successfully registered, the return value is a message identifier in the range 0xC000 through 0xFFFF. If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError().
member.remarks: The RegisterWindowMessage function is typically used to register messages for communicating between two cooperating applications. If two different applications register the same message string, the applications return the same message value. The message remains registered until the session ends. Only use RegisterWindowMessage when more than one application must process the same message. For sending private messages within a window class, an application can use any integer in the range WM_USER through 0x7FFF. (Messages in this range are private to a window class, not to an application. For example, predefined control classes such as BUTTON, EDIT, LISTBOX, and COMBOBOX may use values in this range.)

member.name: M:Native.User32.GetForegroundWindow
member.summary: Retrieves a handle to the foreground window (the window with which the user is currently working). The system assigns a slightly higher priority to the thread that creates the foreground window than it does to other threads.
member.returns: The return value is a handle to the foreground window. The foreground window can be IntPtr.Zero in certain circumstances, such as when a window is losing activation.

member.name: M:Native.User32.UpdateLayeredWindow(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,Native.POINT@,Native.SIZE@,System.IntPtr,Native.POINT@,System.Int32,Native.BLENDFUNCTION@,Native.ULW)
member.summary: Updates the position, size, shape, content, and translucency of a layered window.
member.param: A handle to a layered window. A layered window is created by specifying WS_EX_LAYERED when creating the window with the CreateWindowEx function. Windows 8: The WS_EX_LAYERED style is supported for top-level windows and child windows. Previous Windows versions support WS_EX_LAYERED only for top-level windows.

A handle to a DC for the screen. This handle is obtained by specifying NULL when calling the function. It is used for palette color matching when the window contents are updated. If hdcDst isNULL, the default palette will be used. If hdcSrc is NULL, hdcDst must be NULL.
A pointer to a structure that specifies the new screen position of the layered window. If the current position is not changing, pptDst can be NULL.
A pointer to a structure that specifies the new size of the layered window. If the size of the window is not changing, psize can be NULL. If hdcSrc is NULL, psize must be NULL.

A handle to a DC for the surface that defines the layered window. This handle can be obtained by calling the CreateCompatibleDC function. If the shape and visual context of the window are not changing, hdcSrc can be NULL.
A pointer to a structure that specifies the location of the layer in the device context. If hdcSrc is NULL, pptSrc should be NULL.
A structure that specifies the color key to be used when composing the layered window. To generate a COLORREF, use the RGB macro.
A pointer to a structure that specifies the transparency value to be used when composing the layered window.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

member.name: M:Native.User32.AnimateWindow(System.IntPtr,System.UInt32,Native.AW)
member.summary: Enables you to produce special effects when showing or hiding windows. There are four types of animation: roll, slide, collapse or expand, and alpha-blended fade.
member.param: A handle to the window to animate. The calling thread must own this window.
The time it takes to play the animation, in milliseconds. Typically, an animation takes 200 milliseconds to play.
The type of animation. Note that, by default, these flags take effect when showing a window. To take effect when hiding a window, use and a logical OR operator with the appropriate flags.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is true. If the function fails, the return value is false.

A handle to the update region. If both the and parameters are IntPtr.Zero, the entire client area is added to the update region.

member.name: M:Native.User32.MapWindowPoints(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,Native.POINT[],System.Int32)
member.summary: The MapWindowPoints function converts (maps) a set of points from a coordinate space relative to one window to a coordinate space relative to another window.
member.param: A handle to the window from which points are converted. If this parameter is NULL or HWND_DESKTOP, the points are presumed to be in screen coordinates.
A handle to the window to which points are converted. If this parameter is NULL or HWND_DESKTOP, the points are converted to screen coordinates.

A pointer to an array of POINT structures that contain the set of points to be converted. The points are in device units. This parameter can also point to a RECT structure, in which case the cPoints parameter should be set to 2.
The number of POINT structures in the array pointed to by the lpPoints parameter.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the low-order word of the return value is the number of pixels added to the horizontal coordinate of each source point in order to compute the horizontal coordinate of each destination point. (In addition to that, if precisely one of hWndFrom and hWndTo is mirrored, then each resulting horizontal coordinate is multiplied by -1.) The high-order word is the number of pixels added to the vertical coordinate of each source point in order to compute the vertical coordinate of each destination point.

member.name: M:Native.User32.MapWindowPoints(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,Native.POINT@,System.Int32)
member.summary: The MapWindowPoints function converts (maps) a set of points from a coordinate space relative to one window to a coordinate space relative to another window.
member.param: A handle to the window from which points are converted. If this parameter is NULL or HWND_DESKTOP, the points are presumed to be in screen coordinates.
A handle to the window to which points are converted. If this parameter is NULL or HWND_DESKTOP, the points are converted to screen coordinates.

A pointer to an array of POINT structures that contain the set of points to be converted. The points are in device units. This parameter can also point to a RECT structure, in which case the cPoints parameter should be set to 2.
The number of POINT structures in the array pointed to by the lpPoints parameter.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the low-order word of the return value is the number of pixels added to the horizontal coordinate of each source point in order to compute the horizontal coordinate of each destination point. (In addition to that, if precisely one of hWndFrom and hWndTo is mirrored, then each resulting horizontal coordinate is multiplied by -1.) The high-order word is the number of pixels added to the vertical coordinate of each source point in order to compute the vertical coordinate of each destination point.

member.summary: One or more of the input parameters is invalid.

member.name: F:Native.StretchBltMode.BLACKONWHITE
member.summary: Performs a Boolean AND operation using the color values for the eliminated and existing pixels. If the bitmap is a monochrome bitmap, this mode preserves black pixels at the expense of white pixels.

member.name: F:Native.StretchBltMode.WHITEONBLACK
member.summary: Performs a Boolean OR operation using the color values for the eliminated and existing pixels. If the bitmap is a monochrome bitmap, this mode preserves white pixels at the expense of black pixels.

member.name: F:Native.StretchBltMode.COLORONCOLOR
member.summary: Deletes the pixels. This mode deletes all eliminated lines of pixels without trying to preserve their information.

member.name: F:Native.StretchBltMode.HALFTONE
member.summary: Maps pixels from the source rectangle into blocks of pixels in the destination rectangle. The average color over the destination block of pixels approximates the color of the source pixels. After setting the HALFTONE stretching mode, an application must call the SetBrushOrgEx function to set the brush origin. If it fails to do so, brush misalignment occurs.
